name: Lazy Lasagna
description: This five-ingredient lazy lasagna recipe is perfect for busy weeknights. It captures all the flavor of traditional lasagna, but it’s ready to eat in only 30 minutes.
recipeIngredient: 8 ounces uncooked lasagna noodles, broken into 2-inch pieces
1 cup shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese, divided
1 jar (24 ounces) pasta sauce with meat

recipeInstructions.name: Make the pasta and the cheese mixture
recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400°F. Cook the lasagna noodles according to the package directions. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, mix the ricotta cheese, 1/2 cup of the mozzarella cheese, and the Parmesan cheese. Drain the cooked noodles, and shake off any excess water. Stir the cooked noodles into the cheese mixture. Test Kitchen Tip: Stir the cooked lasagna noodles into the cheese mixture right after draining. Otherwise, they may stick together. If you cook them ahead of time, follow one of our tips for cooking pasta, and toss the noodles in a small amount of olive oil after draining.

recipeInstructions.name: Layer the lasagna
recipeInstructions.text: Spread 1 cup of the pasta sauce into a greased 11x7-inch baking dish. Layer half of the cheese mixture into the baking dish, followed by 1 cup of pasta sauce. Repeat the layers with the remaining cheese mixture and pasta sauce. Top with the remaining mozzarella cheese.

recipeInstructions.name: Bake the lasagna
recipeInstructions.text: Cover the baking dish with greased aluminum foil. Bake for 10 to 15 minutes, until heated through. Editor’s Tip: This dish doesn't take long since all the components are already cooked. However, it's important to bring the lazy lasagna to food-safe cooking temperatures. For casseroles, that’s 165°.

review.reviewBody: I think my husband likes this one as much as regular fussy lasagna.  The noodles have a tendency to stick together; it's helpful to toss them with a tiny bit of olive oil (or cooking spray) right in the colander after draining.  Spinach lasagna is a favorite around here, so if I have it I add a layer of fresh baby spinach -- no chopping or pre-cooking required.  You can add any leftover meat, vegetables, or cheese you have; it always turns out yummy.
This is a good recipe. I did make one change. I added a pound of Italian sausage which upped the flavor perfectly. Was good with garlic toast and a salad. Better the next day.

I love this recipe because it has the flavors of lasagna without the work. Instead of the pasta sauce with meat in it I used a half pound of ground beef. It doesn't add any more prep time because you're browning the meat while waiting for the noodles to cook. I don't ever use those spaghetti sauces that have meat in them because you have no idea what kind of meat is in there and it just seems too fake. I didn't have the problem other people said with the noodles sticking together, but maybe people let the noodles cool off too long? I was tempted to let them cool a long time because I felt like the cheese would melt when I mixed it with the noodles, but actually it was fine even though they were pretty hot. For the pasta I used mafalda. I would definitely use that because you don't have to break the noodles; they're already the perfect size and shape, basically little mini lasagna noodles. I did have to search at a few stores to find it, but if you look online you can easily find which grocery store in your area carries it. I also did what it said in the tips and used a shredded Italian cheese blend.

This sounds pretty good and great way to use up some odds n ends on various pastas. A quick and what I call my cheater lasagna is instead of noodles, I use frozen (or fresh) cheese or the cheese & spinach ravioli as the noodles. Add your favorite meat (less) sauce and sprinkle some more different (fresh mozz, parm, etc) cheese in between. I usually make this after I make spaghetti and have extra meat sauce. I just thin it out a smidge with milk or cream if it's too thick.
This was so good and so easy. Would definitely make again.

This is a great recipe. I did make some changes. I used 10 to 12 ounces of lean ground beef which I cooked and then added a 24 ounce jar of pasta sauce (I use Classico tomato basil). I also used bowtie pasta because I had that on hand. I think the lasagna noodles would probably work better. I didn't have a problem with the noodles sticking together when I added them to the cheese mixture immediately after draining but maybe the bowtie don't stick together like the lasagna noodles do. I am single so I have leftovers and have found it tastes better the 2nd or 3rd night. I freeze 3 servings in individual containers and they turn out great (thaw overnight in the fridge and then put in the microwave).

This sounds like a really great recipe, and easy to do, which is what I am all about these days. That being said, even when I made lasagna the old way, I never boiled my noodles. What's more, is you can use regular lasagna noodles... You don't have to buy the special ones. The only thing is when you layer any lasagna, just make sure that the noodles are covered with plenty of sauce! The cheese layer on top just kind of seals the whole thing in. I think that the layers stick together much easier too. It is always worked for me and my kids had me making it for them for years and years! Be well, everyone!
this was by far one of my favorite variations of lasagna. It was so easy to put together.

This was a great lasagna. My boys just loved that they could break up the noodles. I don’t like to make any changes when I first make a new recipes but my boys will not eat ricotta cheese. So in place I used cottage cheese. It came out great and will make again just the same. Also I did read about the noodles sticking together so in the boiling water I added some olive oil just before I added the noodles. It worked very well.

The taste is great because, well, it’s lasagna.  The issue I have is that it’s still a bit fussy—the noodles stick together when mixing with the cheeses.  I had to keep reaching into the bowl to separate them, which was messy.   I think the only way to make lasagna easier is to use no bake noodles.  I’ll try it again and update if I have an easier time next time.  I used non-meat sauce to make it vegetarian.

The taste is great because, well, it’s lasagna.  The issue for me is that it’s almost as much work as regular lasagna.   By draining the noodles well (as instructed), they stuck together when mixing with the cheese, so I had to keep reaching in the bowl to pull them apart.  And there is still plenty of layering to do.  I think the only way to make lasagna less fussy is to use no-boil noodles.I used non-meat sauce to make it vegetarian.

video.name: Weeknight Lazy Lasagna
video.description: Check out this video for how to make Weeknight Lazy Lasagna
